Project.Brief history of your project and organi: EPIC-KITCHENS, study daily activities from a first-person view, using head-mounted cameras in real kitchens. The dataset has grown over the years and now includes over 100 hours of video, thousands of labeled actions, and detailed object interactions. It helps researchers train and test AI models in areas like action recognition and video understanding.
Project.Describe the data being stored onto File:
Dataset include egocentric video recordings and rich annotations, forming a benchmark designed for evaluating action recognition, anticipation, and object interaction in untrimmed, real-world kitchen environments. This dataset supports cutting-edge machine learning research in areas like computer vision, robotics, and human–AI interaction.

Content Types:
1. High-resolution first-person videos capturing natural, unscripted kitchen activities across diverse users and environments. (Approximate 1 PiB)
2. Temporal annotations of over 90,000 action segments, marking the start and end of daily activities. (Approximate 400 TiB)
3. Metadata including narrations, object labels, action classes, and training/testing splits. (Approximate 500 TiB)
4. Derived data such as optical flow, audio transcripts, object masks (from VISOR), and model benchmark results. (Approximate 500 TiB)

Each SP will store approximately 2.4 PiB, totaling 12 PiB across the network.
Project.How do you plan to prepare the dataset: To store the data, it is first uploaded and assigned a unique Content Identifier (CID). The data is then divided into smaller pieces, encoded, and replicated multiple times to ensure reliability. These pieces are sealed into storage sectors. Storage providers manage the full process, including pre-commitment, sealing, and final commitment, and they regularly submit cryptographic proofs to confirm the data’s integrity over time. Using the CID, the original data can later be located, decoded, and retrieved.
